Fire struck one of our country holdings, leaving only ruins on its way...
A flood in one of our provinces just destroyed many coastal villages!
OK
Argh!
We shall rebuild immediatly
The Rain is continuing in [Root.GetName] and we haven't seen a blue sky for weeks. We need sufficient rain for our fields, but exessive rain will cause a bad crop in comming autumn.
May [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName] help us!
The weather in [Root.GetName] is extremely cold in this year. A cool summer is welcome, however poor people are dying at cold and peasants begin to worry about their crops in autumn.
[Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName], please help us!
Because of bad weathers or deamon's work, the crops in [Root.GetName] is terrible in this year. We have to prepare the coming food shortage.
Let's hope that we can survive this winter.

The bad crops brought a serious famine in [Root.GetName]! There is nothing to eat and the peasants sell their family as slave. They might be still happier than the people who have been dead at hungry.
Buy foods and help poor peasants and citizens!
Let them eat cake!
Thanks to the protection of [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName], we had good crops in [Root.GetName]. We can hold a great harvest feast in this year!
We won't have to worry about the winter!
The Great Famine of 1315-1317

The Great Famine of 1315?317 (occasionally dated 1315?322) was the first of a series of large scale crises that struck Northern Europe early in the fourteenth century. From the Pyrenees to Russia and from Scotland to Italy it caused millions of deaths over an extended number of years and marks a clear end to an earlier period of growth and prosperity during the eleventh to thirteenth centuries. Starting with bad weather in spring 1315, universal crop failures lasted through 1316 until summer harvest in 1317, Europe did not fully recover until 1325.
This is dreadful news.

Pillaging

Sieges could drag on for months and even years, and the besieging troops had to forage the countryside for supplies. These foraging parties could sometimes devolve into looting and outright vandalism. This was the case in [Root.Location.GetName], where our troops have have pillaged and torched one of the province's buildings.
It can't be helped
A building goes up in flames
The besieging troops have destroyed a building in [From.Location.GetName]!
Bastards!
